questions.text: Identify the stage of sleep based on the EEG shown below: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) REM

 

The EEG provided shows a pattern that mimics an awake state, which is indicative of REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep. REM sleep is characterized by specific EEG, EOG (electro-oculogram), and EMG (electromyogram) patterns:

 

  1. EEG (Electroencephalogram): During REM sleep, the EEG shows low amplitude, mixed frequency activity that resembles the awake state. This is in contrast to the high amplitude, low-frequency waves seen in NREM (Non-Rapid Eye Movement) sleep stages.
  2. EOG (Electro-oculogram): The EOG shows rapid eye movements, which are characteristic of REM sleep. These movements are visible as sharp spikes or fluctuations in the EOG tracing.
  3. EMG (Electromyogram): The EMG shows muscle atonia or paralysis, which is another hallmark of REM sleep. This paralysis prevents the sleeper from acting out their dreams. Only the diaphragm and extraocular muscles remain active during REM sleep.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. NREM1: This is the lightest stage of sleep, characterized by a transition from wakefulness to sleep. The EEG shows a mix of alpha and theta waves, with some slow eye movements, but it does not resemble the awake state as closely as REM sleep does.

 

Option B. NREM2: This stage is marked by sleep spindles and K-complexes on the EEG. It is a deeper stage of sleep than NREM1 but does not show the rapid eye movements or muscle atonia seen in REM sleep.

 

Option C. NREM3: Also known as slow-wave sleep (SWS), this stage is characterized by high amplitude, low-frequency delta waves on the EEG. It is the deepest stage of NREM sleep and does not resemble the awake state.

 

Educational Objective:

 

REM sleep is characterized by EEG patterns similar to wakefulness, rapid eye movements on EOG, and muscle atonia on EMG.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT indicative of underlying serious pathology in headache? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic Cocaine use

 

While acute cocaine use can lead to serious complications such as intracranial hemorrhage, chronic cocaine use does not typically present as a headache warning sign for serious pathology unless associated with acute episodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age > 50: New onset headache in individuals over 50 years of age is a red flag and suggests the possibility of serious conditions such as giant cell arteritis or intracranial mass lesions.

 

Option B. Temporal tenderness: This is often a sign of temporal arteritis (giant cell arteritis), a serious condition that can lead to blindness if not treated promptly.

 

Option D. Subacute progression over 4 weeks: This indicates a progressive condition such as a brain tumor or increased intracranial pressure, which are serious pathologies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic cocaine use is not typically indicative of a serious underlying pathology in headache unless associated with acute episodes.

 

Headache Symptoms That Suggest a Serious Underlying Disorder

 

  • Sudden-onset headache
  • First severe headache
  • "Worst" headache ever
  • Vomiting that precedes headache
  • Subacute worsening over days or weeks
  • Pain induced by bending, lifting, coughing
  • Pain that disturbs sleep or presents immediately upon awakening
  • Known systemic illness
  • Onset after age 55
  • Fever or unexplained systemic signs
  • Abnormal neurologic examination
  • Pain associated with local tenderness, e.g., region of temporal artery

questions.text: Interventional technique used for the management of cerebral aneurysm: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coiling

 

The management of cerebral aneurysms, particularly berry aneurysms, involves two primary interventional techniques: clipping and coiling.

 

  • Coiling: This is an endovascular procedure where a catheter is inserted through the femoral artery and navigated to the aneurysm. Coils are then deployed into the aneurysm to induce thrombosis and prevent rupture. Coiling has lower morbidity and mortality rates compared to surgical clipping and is preferred if the aneurysm is accessible for endovascular treatment.
  • Clipping: This involves a craniotomy where the skull is opened, and a clip is placed at the neck of the aneurysm to isolate it from the circulation. While effective, it is more invasive compared to coiling.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Embolization: While embolization is used in various vascular interventions, it is not the preferred technique for managing cerebral aneurysms.

 

Option C. Basal stent placement: Stents may be used as an adjunct to coiling to support the coil mass and ensure complete occlusion of the aneurysm, but stent placement alone is not effective for managing aneurysms.

 

Option D. Balloon Angioplasty: This technique is used to dilate narrowed blood vessels but is not suitable for treating aneurysms as it can worsen the aneurysm by increasing the risk of rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The preferred interventional technique for the management of cerebral aneurysms is endovascular coiling due to its lower morbidity and mortality compared to surgical clipping.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presented with left facial weakness. Routine lab workup was normal. What is the next best step in management? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Corticosteroids

 

The presentation of left facial weakness with normal routine lab workup suggests Bell's palsy, an idiopathic condition characterized by sudden onset of unilateral lower motor neuron facial paralysis. Bell's palsy is a diagnosis of exclusion and is the most common cause of unilateral facial paralysis.

 

Corticosteroids: The first-line treatment for Bell's palsy is corticosteroids. They are most effective when started within 72 hours of symptom onset. Early treatment with corticosteroids can significantly improve the chances of complete recovery. A typical regimen is prednisolone or prednisone.

 

Dosage: Prednisone 60-80 mg per day for 5-7 days, followed by a taper over the next 5-7 days.

 

Note – In the severity grading system, House-Brackmann grading, if the patient has Grade 4 or Grade 5 severity, consider adding antivirals such as acyclovir or valacyclovir.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acyclovir: Although acyclovir or other antiviral agents like valacyclovir are sometimes used, their benefit is less clear. They may be considered in severe cases of Bell's palsy, particularly when there is a suspicion of herpes simplex virus involvement, but they are not the primary treatment.

 

Dosage: Valacyclovir 1 gram TID for 7 days or acyclovir 400 mg five times a day for 7-10 days.

 

Note - Valacyclovir has superior bioavailability, superior efficacy, and lower side effects compared to acyclovir.

 

Option C. Antibiotics: There is no role for antibiotics in the treatment of Bell's palsy as it is not caused by a bacterial infection.

 

Option D. Physiotherapy: While physiotherapy, including facial exercises and eye protection measures, can be supportive, it is not the primary treatment and should be considered an adjunct to corticosteroid therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best initial management for a patient with Bell's palsy is corticosteroid therapy. Early administration within 72 hours of symptom onset greatly enhances the likelihood of complete recovery. Antivirals may be added in severe cases, but they are not the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text:
Which of the following clinical features can be encountered in Korsakoff psychosis? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. Amnesia
  2. Confabulation
  3. Ophthalmoplegia
  4. Peripheral neuropathy
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 4

 

Korsakoff psychosis, or Korsakoff syndrome, is a chronic neuropsychiatric syndrome resulting from chronic deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1), commonly associated with chronic alcoholism. It is often considered an irreversible condition, unlike its acute counterpart, Wernicke's encephalopathy, which can be treated with thiamine supplementation.

 

Clinical Features of Korsakoff Psychosis:

 

1. Amnesia: Korsakoff syndrome is characterized by severe memory impairment, both anterograde (inability to form new memories) and retrograde (loss of previously formed memories) amnesia. Long-term memory, however, tends to remain relatively intact.

 

2. Confabulation: Patients often exhibit confabulation, where they fabricate stories to fill gaps in their memory. This is not intentional lying but a way to compensate for memory loss.

 

4. Peripheral Neuropathy: Chronic alcoholics often suffer from peripheral neuropathy due to thiamine deficiency and direct neurotoxic effects of alcohol. This neuropathy involves the axons of peripheral nerves and manifests as numbness, tingling, and pain in the extremities.

 

Other Option:

 

Not a Feature of Korsakoff Psychosis:

 

3. Ophthalmoplegia: This is a feature of Wernicke's encephalopathy, which presents acutely with a triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and confusion. Ophthalmoplegia refers to paralysis or weakness of the eye muscles. It is reversible with thiamine treatment and is not typically seen in the chronic phase of Korsakoff syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Korsakoff psychosis is characterized by severe memory impairment (amnesia), confabulation, and peripheral neuropathy. It does not include ophthalmoplegia, which is a feature of the acute Wernicke's encephalopathy.

questions.text: All of the following are functions of the superior oblique except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adduction

 

Explanation:

 

Adduction is not a function of the superior oblique muscle. Adduction involves moving the eyeball towards the midline (towards the nose), and this movement is primarily mediated by the medial rectus muscle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Abduction: The superior oblique muscle helps in the lateral movement of the eyeball, meaning it moves the eye away from the midline (abduction).

 

Option C. Depression: When the eye is adducted (turned towards the nose), the superior oblique muscle helps to depress the eyeball, moving it downward.

 

Option D. Intorsion: This is the primary function of the superior oblique muscle. Intorsion involves the rotation of the top of the eyeball towards the nose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The superior oblique muscle is one of the extraocular muscles and is innervated by the trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV). The primary functions of the superior oblique muscle can be remembered using the mnemonic "SO-LID":

 

  • Superior Oblique
  • Lateral movement (Abduction)
  • Intorsion
  • Depression

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presented with fever of 102°F with foul-smelling sputum for 5 days. On examination, clubbing was noted in the digits. Chest X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lung abscess

 

The clinical presentation, including fever, foul-smelling sputum, and digital clubbing, suggests a chronic lung infection. The chest X-ray shows a thick-walled cavity with an air-fluid level, which is a characteristic feature of a lung abscess. A lung abscess is a localized area of pus formation within the lung parenchyma, often resulting from aspiration pneumonia or a necrotizing infection. The presence of an air-fluid level within a thick-walled cavity is the hallmark radiographic sign of a lung abscess.

 

Key points:

 

  • Thick-walled cavity: The presence of thick walls around the cavity distinguishes it from other causes of cavitary lung lesions.
  • Air-fluid level: This feature indicates the presence of a fluid collection within the cavity, which is typical of an abscess.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumatocele: Pneumatoceles are thin-walled air-filled cysts usually resulting from trauma or certain infections like Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia. They do not present with thick walls or air-fluid levels as seen in a lung abscess.

 

Option B. Empyema: Empyema is a collection of pus within the pleural space, typically seen on the periphery of the lung rather than centrally. It presents as a pleural-based opacity, often with a split pleura sign on imaging, which is absent in this case.

 

Option C. Pneumothorax: Pneumothorax is the presence of air in the pleural space, leading to lung collapse. It does not present with a thick-walled cavity or air-fluid levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A thick-walled cavity with an air-fluid level on imaging, especially in the context of fever and foul-smelling sputum, is indicative of a lung abscess.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presented with shortness of breath, and further evaluation revealed a right pleural effusion. Upon analysis, pleural fluid showed LDH that is 0.7 times the serum LDH and protein that is 0.6 times the serum protein. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tuberculosis

 

Explanation:

 

The pleural fluid values provided are consistent with an exudative effusion based on Light’s criteria:

 

  • Light’s Criteria for Exudative Effusion (any one of the following):
  • Pleural fluid protein / serum protein ratio > 0.5
  • Pleural fluid LDH / serum LDH ratio > 0.6
  • Pleural fluid LDH > 2/3 the upper limit of normal serum LDH
  • This case satisfies both the first and second criteria:
  • Protein ratio = 0.6 > 0.5
  • LDH ratio = 0.7 > 0.6

 

Therefore, it is an exudative effusion.

 

Tuberculosis is a common cause of exudative pleural effusion, especially in endemic areas like India. The effusion is typically lymphocyte predominant and due to pleural inflammation and increased capillary permeability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heart failure: Commonly causes transudative effusion due to increased hydrostatic pressure.

 

Option C. Hepatic failure: Usually results in transudative effusion, especially in cirrhosis (hepatic hydrothorax), due to low oncotic pressure.

 

Option D. Renal failure: Leads to transudative effusion due to fluid overload or low albumin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tuberculosis causes exudative pleural effusions due to pleural inflammation. In contrast, heart failure, hepatic failure, and renal failure typically cause transudative effusions.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented with acute epigastric pain and nausea. Lab reports showed an increase in serum lipase levels. He received 2L of fluids during admission, and three days after stabilization, he developed sudden breathlessness. Chest X-ray is shown. What is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema

 

The patient’s presentation with acute epigastric pain, nausea, and elevated lipase levels suggests acute pancreatitis. The development of sudden breathlessness and the presence of bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray, in the setting of pancreatitis, is highly indicative of Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS), a form of non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema. ARDS is a severe complication associated with acute pancreatitis and is characterized by bilateral infiltrates on imaging, often symmetric, without evidence of heart failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased PCWP: An increased Pulmonary Capillary Wedge Pressure (PCWP) suggests cardiogenic pulmonary edema, typically seen in heart failure, not ARDS. In ARDS, PCWP is normal or low, as the edema is non-cardiogenic.

 

Option B. Pulmonary thromboembolism: Pulmonary thromboembolism usually presents with sudden onset dyspnea, chest pain, and possibly hemoptysis, but it does not typically cause bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray as seen here.

 

Option D. Aspiration pneumonitis: Aspiration pneumonitis commonly causes unilateral infiltrates initially, especially in the right lower lobe, due to the anatomical position of the bronchus. While aspiration can progress to ARDS, the history provided does not suggest aspiration, making it an unlikely primary diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ARDS is a potential severe complication of acute pancreatitis, presenting with non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema characterized by bilateral infiltrates and normal PCWP

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient presents with left-sided arm and leg weakness, right-sided facial paralysis, and horizontal gaze palsy. Based on the clinical presentation, which of the following is most consistent with the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Foville syndrome

 

Foville syndrome is a brainstem stroke syndrome characterized by contralateral hemiparesis (weakness on the opposite side of the body) and ipsilateral cranial nerve palsies, specifically involving cranial nerves VI (abducens nerve) and VII (facial nerve), as well as horizontal gaze palsy due to involvement of the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) or medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF). The combination of left-sided hemiparesis, right-sided facial paralysis, and horizontal gaze palsy is classical for Foville syndrome, making it the correct diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Locked In syndrome: This syndrome results from a lesion in the ventral pons, leading to quadriparesis (paralysis of all four limbs) and loss of voluntary movement except for vertical eye movements and blinking. It does not match the presentation of unilateral weakness with specific cranial nerve involvement.

 

Option C. Millard-Gubler syndrome: This syndrome involves contralateral hemiparesis with ipsilateral cranial nerve VI (abducens nerve) and VII (facial nerve) palsy but does not present with horizontal gaze palsy, which is the key differentiating feature from Foville syndrome.

 

Option D. Wallenberg syndrome: Also known as lateral medullary syndrome, Wallenberg syndrome primarily involves sensory deficits, including pain and temperature loss on one side of the face and the opposite side of the body. It does not typically involve significant motor weakness or cranial nerve VI or VII palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Foville syndrome involves contralateral hemiparesis, ipsilateral cranial nerve palsies, and horizontal gaze palsy due to brainstem involvement, distinguishing it from other stroke syndromes.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of recurrent falls presented with headache and confusion. CT scan of the patient is shown. Which of the following is correct? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic SDH (Subdural Hemorrhage)

 

The CT scan of the patient shows a crescent-shaped hypodensity on the lateral side of the brain, indicative of a subdural hemorrhage (SDH). In the context of this patient, the hypodensity suggests that the bleeding is chronic. Chronic SDH typically appears darker (hypodense) on CT imaging due to the breakdown of blood products over time.

 

Chronic SDH is common in elderly patients, especially those with a history of recurrent falls or those taking antiplatelet or anticoagulant medications. This condition can occur after even trivial trauma, which elderly patients may not recall. The bleeding occurs between the dura mater and the arachnoid membrane, leading to the characteristic crescent shape seen on imaging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intraparenchymal hemorrhage: This type of hemorrhage occurs within the brain tissue itself and typically appears as a hyperdense (bright) area on CT in the acute phase. It does not present with the crescent shape seen in subdural hemorrhages.

 

Option C. Subarachnoid hemorrhage: This hemorrhage occurs in the space between the brain and the arachnoid membrane, often appearing as bright, hyperdense areas in the sulci and basal cisterns on CT. It does not have the characteristic crescent shape of a subdural hemorrhage.

 

Option D. Epidural hemorrhage: Epidural hemorrhages usually present as a biconvex (lens-shaped) hyperdensity on CT, typically associated with trauma, especially to the middle meningeal artery. It is not consistent with the crescent-shaped hypodensity seen in this patient’s scan.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic subdural hemorrhage presents as a crescent-shaped hypodense area on CT and is common in elderly patients with a history of falls or those on anticoagulant therapy.

questions.text: A patient presents with headaches, confusion, and has recently been diagnosed with a brain tumor. MRI of the brain revealed a cerebellar mass. The family history reveals occurrences of both brain and kidney tumors. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with this clinical presentation? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome


Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome is an inherited disorder characterized by the development of multiple tumors and cysts in different parts of the body. This syndrome is strongly associated with cerebellar hemangioblastomas (a type of brain tumor) and renal cell carcinoma (RCC), among other types of tumors. The clinical presentation of a cerebellar mass along with a family history of both brain and kidney tumors is highly suggestive of VHL syndrome. The presence of these tumors in a familial pattern fits the diagnostic criteria for VHL.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neurofibromatosis: This genetic condition often presents with nerve sheath tumors (neurofibromas), optic gliomas, and café-au-lait spots but does not typically involve both cerebellar tumors and kidney tumors such as RCC.

 

Option B. Li-Fraumeni syndrome: Li-Fraumeni is associated with a variety of cancers, including brain tumors, sarcomas, and breast cancer, due to TP53 mutations. However, it does not specifically link cerebellar and kidney tumors as seen in VHL.

 

Option D. Tuberous sclerosis: This condition is characterized by benign tumors in multiple organs, including the brain (subependymal giant cell astrocytomas) and kidneys (angiomyolipomas). However, it does not fit the combination of cerebellar tumors and RCC typical of VHL syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:


Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome is associated with cerebellar hemangioblastomas and renal cell carcinoma, especially in the context of familial occurrences. Recognizing the combination of brain and kidney tumors should prompt consideration of VHL.

choices.text: B scan of both the eyes

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented with GTCS (Generalized Tonic-Clonic Seizures) and was admitted. CECT is shown below. Which of the following can be useful in establishing the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NMR spectroscopy

 

The CECT scan shows a single ring-enhancing lesion near the parieto-occipital region, which raises differential diagnoses, including brain abscess, primary CNS lymphoma, tuberculoma, and neurocysticercosis. Among these, the most relevant differential in this patient is tuberculoma versus neurocysticercosis. NMR (Nuclear Magnetic Resonance) spectroscopy is useful in distinguishing between these conditions. In tuberculoma, NMR spectroscopy typically shows a characteristic lipid and/or lactate peak, while in neurocysticercosis, it shows multiple amino acid peaks. This makes NMR spectroscopy the most appropriate tool for establishing the diagnosis in this clinical context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CBNAAT of CSF: CBNAAT (Cartridge Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test) of CSF is primarily used to confirm TB meningitis, which is not the primary suspicion in this patient. The clinical presentation does not fit TB meningitis, and the test is unlikely to be positive in cases of tuberculoma.

 

Option B. PET scan: A PET scan is typically useful for assessing metabolic activity in tumors but is not the best initial choice for differentiating tuberculoma from neurocysticercosis.

 

Option D. B scan of both the eyes: A B scan, or ultrasound of the eyes, is used if intraocular neurocysticercosis is suspected. However, there is no indication of ocular involvement in this patient, making it less relevant for this particular diagnostic dilemma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NMR spectroscopy is valuable in distinguishing between tuberculoma and neurocysticercosis, especially when a single ring-enhancing lesion is present on imaging.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of Wilson’s disease presents with neurological manifestations. Which of the following is the best diagnostic modality? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hepatic copper content

 

Wilson’s disease is a genetic disorder that leads to excessive accumulation of copper in the liver, brain, and other tissues, causing hepatic, neurological, and psychiatric symptoms. The gold standard diagnostic test for Wilson’s disease, particularly when definitive diagnosis is required, is measuring hepatic copper content through a liver biopsy.

 

A hepatic copper content greater than 250 micrograms per gram of dry liver weight confirms the diagnosis of Wilson’s disease. Although other conditions, such as chronic cholestatic diseases, can also lead to increased hepatic copper, this remains the most specific and sensitive diagnostic test for Wilson’s disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum ceruloplasmin: This is a screening test used in diagnosing Wilson’s disease. In Wilson’s disease, ceruloplasmin levels are typically reduced. However, it is not specific and can be affected by other conditions, making it unsuitable as a definitive diagnostic test.

 

Option B. Urinary copper excretion: Urinary copper excretion is often elevated in Wilson’s disease (greater than 100 micrograms in 24 hours). This test is supportive but not definitive, as increased copper excretion can also occur in other liver conditions.

 

Option D. Serum copper: Measuring serum copper is generally not useful in the diagnosis of Wilson’s disease. Total serum copper is often low because most serum copper is bound to ceruloplasmin, which is reduced in Wilson's disease. Free copper (non-ceruloplasmin-bound) may be elevated, but this measure lacks specificity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The gold standard for diagnosing Wilson’s disease is the assessment of hepatic copper content through liver biopsy, which is essential for definitive diagnosis

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most likely based on the lab values shown - Blood pH 7.28, Na 138 mEq/L, K 2.8 mEq/L, Cl 113 mEq/L, HCO3 12 mEq/L, BUN 3 mg/dL, and creatinine 0.2 mg/dL. Urinalysis showed a urinary pH of 9. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type 1 RTA

 

The patient’s laboratory findings indicate metabolic acidosis with a blood pH of 7.28, low bicarbonate (HCO3 of 12 mEq/L), and normal anion gap, suggesting a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA). The hypokalemia (K 2.8 mEq/L) and a urinary pH of 9, which indicates alkaline urine, are key diagnostic clues.

 

Type 1 Renal Tubular Acidosis (RTA), also known as distal RTA, is characterized by the inability of the distal nephron to acidify the urine, resulting in a persistently high urinary pH (usually >5.5). This condition often presents with hypokalemia due to impaired hydrogen ion excretion. The patient’s alkaline urine and hypokalemia strongly support the diagnosis of Type 1 RTA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 4 RTA: Type 4 RTA typically presents with hyperkalemia due to aldosterone deficiency or resistance, which is not seen here. The presence of hypokalemia rules out this diagnosis.

 

Option C. Type 2 RTA: Type 2 RTA, or proximal RTA, involves a defect in bicarbonate reabsorption. While it also presents with metabolic acidosis and hypokalemia, the urine can often be acidified after a bicarbonate load, resulting in a lower pH. The high urinary pH observed here is not consistent with Type 2 RTA.

 

Option D. Respiratory acidosis: This condition would present with elevated pCO2 and acidemia due to impaired ventilation. The patient's normal anion gap and metabolic acidosis rule out respiratory acidosis as a diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type 1 RTA (distal RTA) is identified by a combination of metabolic acidosis, hypokalemia, and an inability to acidify the urine, leading to an alkaline urinary pH, which is a distinct feature not seen in other RTAs.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with altered mental status, tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypertension after consuming an unknown substance. On evaluation, he has high anion gap metabolic acidosis and hypocalcemia. Which of the following is likely to be the reason for his presentation? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ethylene glycol

 

Ethylene glycol poisoning typically presents with high anion gap metabolic acidosis due to its toxic metabolites, glycolic acid and oxalic acid. The formation of oxalic acid can lead to hypocalcemia because it binds calcium, forming insoluble calcium oxalate crystals. These crystals can deposit in the kidneys, leading to acute kidney injury (AKI). The clinical presentation of altered mental status, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypertension, high anion gap metabolic acidosis, and hypocalcemia is highly suggestive of ethylene glycol poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron: Iron toxicity generally presents with gastrointestinal symptoms, metabolic acidosis, and shock but does not cause hypocalcemia. It also typically leads to elevated serum iron levels and liver dysfunction rather than the metabolic acidosis pattern seen here.

 

Option B. Methanol: Methanol poisoning also causes high anion gap metabolic acidosis, but it is primarily associated with visual disturbances (such as blindness) due to its toxic metabolite, formic acid. It does not cause hypocalcemia and has different systemic effects.

 

Option D. Digoxin: Digoxin toxicity typically presents with gastrointestinal symptoms, visual disturbances like xanthopsia (yellow vision), arrhythmias, and hyperkalemia rather than metabolic acidosis and hypocalcemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethylene glycol poisoning presents with high anion gap metabolic acidosis, hypocalcemia, and potential acute kidney injury due to the formation of calcium oxalate crystals from its toxic metabolites.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman with a history of eclampsia is being administered a maintenance dose of magnesium sulfate. When will you stop magnesium sulfate? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urine output of 15 mL/hour

 

Magnesium sulfate is used in the management of eclampsia to prevent seizures. It is essential to monitor the patient for signs of magnesium toxicity, which can be life-threatening. The major parameters to monitor include deep tendon reflexes (e.g., knee jerk), respiratory rate, serum magnesium levels, and urine output.

 

A critical parameter for the continuation of magnesium sulfate therapy is adequate urine output. The minimum urine output required is 100 mL over 4 hours (or about 25 mL/hour). Urine output below this threshold suggests inadequate excretion of magnesium, increasing the risk of toxicity. Therefore, a urine output of 15 mL/hour indicates a need to stop magnesium sulfate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Knee jerk present: The presence of knee jerk reflexes indicates that the patient has not yet reached the initial signs of magnesium toxicity. Stopping magnesium sulfate is not indicated based on this finding alone.

 

Option B. RR of 18/min: This is a normal respiratory rate, indicating that there is no respiratory depression. Stopping magnesium sulfate is not necessary in this scenario.

 

Option C. S. Mg level of 6 mEq/L: This serum magnesium level is within the therapeutic range for eclampsia management. Therefore, it does not necessitate stopping the medication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Magnesium sulfate should be discontinued if the urine output is less than 100 mL over 4 hours, indicating impaired magnesium excretion and a risk of toxicity.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with headache, palpitations, and hypertension. On evaluation, his urinary VMA and catecholamines were elevated. Imaging revealed an adrenal mass, and the patient underwent surgery and resection. Histology of the mass was shown. Which of the following is true regarding the condition? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Can be seen in MEN 2A

 

The patient’s symptoms, elevated urinary vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) and catecholamines, and the presence of an adrenal mass indicate pheochromocytoma, a catecholamine-secreting tumor. Pheochromocytomas can present with classic symptoms of headache, palpitations, and hypertension.

 

Association with MEN 2A: Pheochromocytomas are often seen in multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A (MEN2A) and type 2B (MEN2B) syndromes. These syndromes are genetic conditions characterized by medullary thyroid cancer, pheochromocytoma, and other endocrine abnormalities. MEN2A specifically involves pheochromocytoma, medullary thyroid carcinoma, and parathyroid hyperplasia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mostly in children: Pheochromocytomas are not mostly seen in children; they occur predominantly in adults. Only about 10% of cases are seen in children.

 

Option B. Mostly malignant: Most pheochromocytomas are benign. Only about 10-15% of these tumors are malignant, contrary to the statement that they are "mostly malignant."

 

Option D. Mostly bilateral: Pheochromocytomas are usually unilateral, with only about 10-12% being bilateral. Bilateral cases are more commonly associated with genetic conditions like MEN syndromes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pheochromocytomas can be seen in MEN2A and MEN2B syndromes, which are genetic conditions associated with multiple endocrine tumors, including pheochromocytoma

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient presents with lethargy and tiredness. On examination, he has hyperpigmentation around the lips. His BP is 90/60 mm Hg and heart rate is 110/min. Labs revealed a Na⁺ of 125 mEq/L and a K⁺ of 5.5 mEq/L. What is the most appropriate treatment? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone

 

The patient’s presentation suggests primary adrenal insufficiency, specifically Addison's disease, which is characterized by lethargy, hypotension, hyperpigmentation, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia. Primary adrenal insufficiency involves a deficiency of both glucocorticoids (cortisol) and mineralocorticoids (aldosterone). Therefore, the appropriate management is to replace both with hydrocortisone (a glucocorticoid) and fludrocortisone (a mineralocorticoid) to correct the hormonal deficiencies and electrolyte imbalances.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ACTH: ACTH (adrenocorticotropic hormone) is not a treatment; it is used diagnostically to assess adrenal function. It is not appropriate as a therapeutic measure in adrenal insufficiency.

 

Option C. Dexamethasone: In primary adrenal insufficiency, dexamethasone alone is inadequate because it does not address the mineralocorticoid deficiency.

 

Option D. NaCl infusion: While saline infusion can help correct electrolyte disturbances temporarily, it does not address the underlying hormone deficiencies and is not sufficient as a standalone treatment for adrenal insufficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary adrenal insufficiency requires replacement therapy with both glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids. Hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone are the mainstays of treatment.

choices.text: GH levels after 2 hours of administration of 75g glucose

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with large, sweaty hands, macroglossia, and prominent frontal bossing. The patient also reports increasing shoe size and difficulty wearing rings that previously fit. Considering the clinical features, which of the following tests is the most appropriate initial investigation? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Age-matched IGF-1 levels

 

The clinical features described—large hands, macroglossia, prominent frontal bossing, and changes in shoe and ring sizes—are characteristic of acromegaly, a condition caused by excessive growth hormone (GH) secretion, usually due to a pituitary adenoma. The initial and most appropriate screening test for acromegaly is measuring age-matched IGF-1 (Insulin-like Growth Factor-1) levels. IGF-1 reflects average GH levels and is less variable than GH, making it a reliable marker for diagnosing acromegaly. The test must be age-matched because IGF-1 levels naturally decline with age, and using incorrect age ranges could lead to misinterpretation of results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GHRH levels: Measuring GHRH is rarely useful in the initial assessment and is reserved for cases where ectopic GHRH secretion is suspected. It is not a primary diagnostic tool for acromegaly.

 

Option C. Random GH levels: Random measurement of GH is not reliable due to the pulsatile nature of GH secretion. Levels fluctuate throughout the day, making this test inappropriate for diagnosing acromegaly.

 

Option D. GH levels after 2 hours of administration of 75g glucose: This is a confirmatory test, not an initial screening test. Normally, GH levels should be suppressed to undetectable levels (<1 ng/mL) following glucose administration. Failure of suppression confirms acromegaly but is not used as the first line of investigation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial test of choice for acromegaly is measuring age-matched IGF-1 levels, which serves as a reliable screening method due to its consistent reflection of GH levels over time.

choices.text: NHL - advanced stage - treated with radiotherapy

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman came with complaints of fever, night sweats, generalized itching, and unintentional weight loss of 10% in the last 3 months. On examination, she has enlarged cervical and axillary lymph nodes. The lymph node examination and biopsy showed the following picture. What would the likely diagnosis and treatment option be? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hodgkin's Lymphoma - ABVD regimen

 

The clinical presentation of fever, night sweats, unintentional weight loss (collectively known as B symptoms), along with generalized itching and lymphadenopathy, strongly suggests a diagnosis of Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL). The biopsy finding of classic Reed-Sternberg cells, which are large abnormal lymphocytes often found in Hodgkin's Lymphoma, confirms this diagnosis.

 

Hodgkin’s Lymphoma is treated primarily with the ABVD regimen, which includes the drugs Adriamycin (doxorubicin), Bleomycin, Vinblastine, and Dacarbazine. This regimen is the standard initial treatment for classical Hodgkin’s Lymphoma and may be supplemented with involved site radiotherapy (ISRT) in select cases. In cases of refractory or relapsed disease, Brentuximab Vedotin, an anti-CD30 monoclonal antibody-drug conjugate, may be added.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NHL - Rituximab monotherapy: The question describes a case of Hodgkin’s lymphoma

 

Option C. NHL - advanced stage - treated with radiotherapy: The question describes a case of Hodgkin’s lymphoma

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis - Started on Prednisolone 40 mg/day: The question describes a case of Hodgkin’s lymphoma

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hodgkin’s Lymphoma is characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells on biopsy and is treated with the ABVD chemotherapy regimen, often combined with radiotherapy in specific cases.

choices.text: Chronic Hepatitis B with HBeAg negative
Chronic Hepatitis B with HBeAg positive

questions.text: A 30-year-old man had an episode of jaundice due to HBV one year back. On follow-up now, he has normal levels of liver enzymes. His current profile is shown in the image. What is the diagnosis for his current condition? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic Hepatitis B with HBeAg positive


The patient had jaundice due to Hepatitis B one year ago and now presents with persistent Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg), which is visible in the profile as the orange line indicating ongoing infection. According to the definition, Chronic Hepatitis B is diagnosed when HBsAg persists for more than six months. In this case, the presence of HBeAg (Hepatitis B e-antigen) positivity indicates active viral replication and higher infectivity, confirming the diagnosis of chronic Hepatitis B with HBeAg positive status.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic Hepatitis B with HBeAg negative: This condition involves the persistence of HBsAg but without the presence of HBeAg. The patient’s profile shows HBeAg positivity, ruling out this option.

 

Option C. Resolved infection: Resolved infection would be characterized by the disappearance of HBsAg and the presence of anti-HBs antibodies. The patient’s profile still shows HBsAg, indicating ongoing infection.

 

Option D. Acute Hepatitis B: Acute Hepatitis B would occur within the first six months of infection. Given that the infection has persisted for over a year, this is a chronic condition.

 

Educational Objective:


Chronic Hepatitis B is defined by the persistence of HBsAg for more than six months. The presence of HBeAg indicates active viral replication, characterizing the infection as HBeAg positive.

choices.text: Flow cytometry is the gold standard for diagnosis
It is an inherited disorder with chronic intravascular hemolysis and frequent exacerbations
Most common cause of death is heart failure and anemia
Sucrose lysis test is useful for confirming the diagnosis

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the diagnosis of Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH)? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flow cytometry is the gold standard for diagnosis

 

Flow cytometry is considered the gold standard for diagnosing PNH as it detects the deficiency of GPI-anchored proteins such as CD55 and CD59 on red blood cells, which are characteristic of this condition. This method is highly sensitive and specific, allowing for the detection of even small populations of PNH cells, making it the most accurate and preferred diagnostic tool.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is an inherited disorder with chronic intravascular hemolysis and frequent exacerbations: PNH is not an inherited disorder; it is an acquired disorder.

 

Option C. Most common cause of death is heart failure and anemia: The most common cause of death in PNH is thromboembolism, not heart failure or anemia.

 

Option D. Sucrose lysis test is useful for confirming the diagnosis: The sucrose lysis test is outdated and is no longer considered reliable or standard in modern diagnostic practices for PNH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flow cytometry is the gold standard for diagnosing PNH, focusing on detecting deficiencies of GPI-anchored proteins such as CD55 and CD59 on blood cells.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presented with fever and myalgia. On examination, he had a diffuse maculopapular rash. Labs revealed a Hb of 14 g/dL, Hematocrit of 55%, Total WBC count of 4000, and platelet count of 25,000. Which of the following is the best prognostic indicator? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hematocrit

 

The clinical presentation and laboratory findings suggest a diagnosis of dengue fever, a common viral infection characterized by fever, rash, myalgia, thrombocytopenia (low platelets), and elevated hematocrit due to plasma leakage.

 

Hematocrit is the best prognostic indicator in dengue fever as it reflects the severity of plasma leakage, which can lead to hypovolemia, shock, and severe dengue. Monitoring hematocrit helps guide fluid management. A rising hematocrit indicates worsening plasma leakage, necessitating aggressive fluid replacement, while a falling hematocrit in a patient with shock suggests the need for blood transfusion. This makes hematocrit a critical marker in the management of dengue, as it directly influences therapeutic decisions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Platelets: While thrombocytopenia is a common finding in dengue and is monitored closely, platelet count alone does not directly guide fluid management or predict disease severity as effectively as hematocrit.

 

Option C. Total Leukocyte Count: Leukopenia (low white blood cell count) is often seen in dengue but does not have significant prognostic value. It is not used to guide treatment decisions.

 

Option D. Albumin: Low albumin levels can occur in severe dengue due to plasma leakage, but albumin is not the primary marker used for monitoring disease progression or guiding treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In dengue fever, hematocrit is the best prognostic indicator as it reflects the extent of plasma leakage and guides fluid management, which is crucial in preventing complications.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presented with a hip fracture. She has a past history of multiple fractures, and DEXA revealed a T-score of -2.7. Which of the following would be increased in her blood profile? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tartrate resistant acid phosphatase

 

The patient's presentation with multiple fractures and a DEXA T-score of -2.7 indicates osteoporosis, a condition characterized by decreased bone density and increased risk of fractures. In osteoporosis, markers of bone resorption (osteoclastic activity) are often elevated due to increased bone turnover.

 

Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) is an enzyme that is specifically expressed by osteoclasts, the cells responsible for bone resorption. Elevated levels of TRAP indicate increased osteoclastic activity, which is a hallmark of bone loss seen in osteoporosis. Thus, TRAP serves as a marker of bone destruction.

 

Other markers of bone resorption include urinary hydroxyproline, N-terminal telopeptide, and C-terminal telopeptide, but TRAP is particularly associated with osteoclastic activity and bone loss, making it the correct answer in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AST (Aspartate Aminotransferase): AST is a liver enzyme and is not associated with bone metabolism or osteoclastic activity. It is typically elevated in liver diseases or muscle injury, not in conditions of increased bone resorption.

 

Option B. ALT (Alanine Aminotransferase): ALT is another liver enzyme elevated in liver damage and is unrelated to bone metabolism or osteoporosis.

 

Option C. LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase): LDH is a non-specific enzyme that may be elevated in a variety of conditions, including tissue damage, hemolysis, and some cancers. It is not specific for bone metabolism or osteoporosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In osteoporosis, markers of increased bone resorption, such as Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP), are elevated due to increased osteoclastic activity. TRAP is specifically associated with bone loss and osteoclastic activity, distinguishing it from other enzymes that are unrelated to bone metabolism.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman came with complaints of weakness and lethargy with a past history of heavy menstrual bleeding. Her peripheral blood smear showed microcytic RBCs. Her lab reports are as follows - Hb 7.9 mg/dl, MCV 65, MCH - low, TIBC - increased, Transferrin saturation - low. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron deficiency anemia

 

Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by microcytic, hypochromic red blood cells with low mean corpuscular volume (MCV) and low mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH). The patient’s lab findings, including a low hemoglobin level (7.9 g/dL), low MCV (65), and low transferrin saturation, are classic for iron deficiency anemia. Additionally, her past history of heavy menstrual bleeding suggests chronic blood loss, which is a common cause of iron deficiency anemia.

 

The elevated total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) and low transferrin saturation further confirm iron deficiency, as the body increases TIBC in an attempt to bind and transport more iron due to the deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemolytic anemia: Hemolytic anemia usually presents with normocytic red blood cells and a high reticulocyte count due to increased red blood cell turnover. It does not present with microcytic RBCs and does not have the iron deficiency profile seen here.

 

Option C. Hypoplastic anemia (Aplastic anemia): This type of anemia involves bone marrow failure, often presenting with pancytopenia (low counts of all blood cells) and normocytic or macrocytic RBCs, not microcytic RBCs. Iron parameters are generally normal or can be elevated due to reduced erythropoiesis.

 

Option D. Megaloblastic anemia: Megaloblastic anemia is characterized by macrocytic RBCs due to deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate, not microcytic RBCs. It does not fit the patient's lab profile of low MCV and iron deficiency markers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron deficiency anemia presents with microcytic, hypochromic RBCs, low hemoglobin, low MCV, increased TIBC, and low transferrin saturation, often caused by chronic blood loss such as heavy menstrual bleeding.

questions.text: A patient with HIV who is currently on antiretroviral therapy consisting of zidovudine, lamivudine, and nevirapine is diagnosed with tuberculosis. Considering potential drug interactions, which of the following TB drugs should be changed in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rifampicin

 

Rifampicin is a potent enzyme inducer of the cytochrome P450 system, particularly CYP3A4, which is involved in the metabolism of many antiretroviral drugs, including nevirapine. This enzyme induction significantly lowers the plasma levels of nevirapine, potentially leading to antiretroviral therapy (ART) failure by reducing the drug's effectiveness against HIV.

 

In practice, when treating a patient with both HIV and tuberculosis, rifampicin is usually continued due to its efficacy and availability. However, the antiretroviral therapy must be adjusted. Specifically, nevirapine should be replaced with an alternative ART drug that does not interact negatively with rifampicin, such as dolutegravir at a double dose or lopinavir/ritonavir at an adjusted dose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoniazid: Isoniazid does not have significant interactions with nevirapine and can be safely used in patients receiving ART.

 

Option C. Ethambutol: Ethambutol does not interact significantly with antiretroviral drugs and is generally safe to use alongside ART.

 

Option D. Streptomycin: Streptomycin does not have major interactions with nevirapine or other antiretroviral drugs, making it safe to use in this combination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rifampicin interacts significantly with nevirapine due to its enzyme-inducing properties, lowering nevirapine levels and risking ART failure. Thus, when co-administered, antiretroviral therapy should be adjusted rather than discontinuing rifampicin.

choices.text: Myxomatous degeneration of the bone marrow

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman presents with complaints of fatigue, jaundice, edema, and hepatosplenomegaly. She had anemia and neutropenia. Her serum creatinine is 3.2 mg/dL, and her bone marrow examination showed 22% plasma cells, and her serum Ig levels were 3.0 g/dL. The bone marrow biopsy is shown below. What is the associated histology? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amyloidosis

 

The clinical presentation and findings in this patient strongly suggest a diagnosis of multiple myeloma with associated AL (amyloid light-chain) amyloidosis.

 

  1. Multiple Myeloma Features: The patient has several features indicative of multiple myeloma, including anemia, renal impairment (high serum creatinine), increased plasma cells in the bone marrow (22%), and elevated immunoglobulin levels (>3 g/dL), all of which are consistent with myeloma-defining events.
  2. Amyloidosis Association: Amyloidosis is a common complication of multiple myeloma, particularly AL amyloidosis, where light chains deposit in tissues, leading to organ dysfunction. The presence of edema (often due to nephrotic syndrome or heart failure from amyloid cardiomyopathy) and hepatosplenomegaly (from amyloid infiltration) supports the diagnosis of amyloidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS): MGUS does not meet the criteria for multiple myeloma as it lacks myeloma-defining events like significant organ damage (CRAB features - hyperCalcemia, Renal failure, Anemia, Bone lesions).

 

Option B. Bone marrow - fibrinoid necrosis: This is not related to the clinical presentation or typical of multiple myeloma with amyloidosis.

 

Option D. Myxomatous degeneration of the bone marrow: This is not associated with the clinical findings or typical complications of multiple myeloma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiple myeloma can be complicated by AL amyloidosis, which leads to symptoms such as edema, hepatosplenomegaly, and organ dysfunction due to amyloid deposits in various tissues.

questions.text: A person was taking an antihypertensive drug prescribed for his hypertension. He was regular in his consumption despite having some constipation, dry mouth, and dizziness. Recently, he went on a trip away from the country and failed to carry his medications with him, and was not taking them since then. Currently, he presented to the OPD with a hypertensive emergency. What is the likely antihypertensive drug? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clonidine

 

Clonidine is a centrally acting alpha-2 agonist used to manage hypertension. It is known for causing side effects such as dry mouth, dizziness, and constipation, which match the symptoms described in the question. Clonidine is particularly notorious for causing rebound hypertension if suddenly discontinued, which can lead to a hypertensive emergency, as seen in this patient who stopped taking his medication during a trip. The abrupt cessation of clonidine leads to a surge in sympathetic activity, resulting in severe hypertension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amlodipine: Amlodipine is a calcium channel blocker that is commonly used to treat hypertension. It is well-tolerated and does not cause rebound hypertension upon sudden discontinuation, making it an unlikely cause of the hypertensive emergency in this case.

 

Option C. Lisinopril: Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor used for hypertension. While it can cause a mild increase in blood pressure upon discontinuation, it does not lead to the severe rebound hypertension seen with clonidine. Moreover, its side effects do not typically include dry mouth, constipation, and dizziness as prominently as clonidine.

 

Option D. Telmisartan: Telmisartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) used in the treatment of hypertension. It does not cause significant withdrawal effects leading to a hypertensive emergency and does not match the side effect profile described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clonidine is associated with rebound hypertension if suddenly stopped, which can lead to a hypertensive emergency. It is crucial for patients on clonidine to taper the medication rather than discontinue it abruptly.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs, when given with erythromycin, can cause QT prolongation and Torsades de pointes? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Astemizole

 

Astemizole is an antihistamine known to cause QT prolongation and an increased risk of Torsades de pointes, especially when combined with other medications that affect cardiac conduction, such as erythromycin. This dangerous interaction occurs because both drugs can interfere with cardiac potassium channels, prolonging the QT interval and predisposing the patient to potentially fatal arrhythmias.

 

Astemizole and terfenadine are notable among antihistamines for their high risk of causing Torsades de pointes, which has led to the withdrawal of terfenadine from the market. Astemizole, though less commonly used, still poses a significant risk when combined with drugs like erythromycin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cetirizine: Cetirizine is a second-generation antihistamine that does not significantly affect the QT interval and is not associated with Torsades de pointes when combined with erythromycin.

 

Option C. Loratadine: Loratadine is another second-generation antihistamine with a good safety profile concerning cardiac conduction and QT interval prolongation, making it a safer choice in patients requiring antihistamine treatment.

 

Option D. Promethazine: Although promethazine is a first-generation antihistamine, it does not carry the same risk of QT prolongation and Torsades de pointes as astemizole when used with erythromycin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Astemizole, when combined with erythromycin, can cause QT prolongation and Torsades de pointes due to its significant effect on cardiac potassium channels, posing a high risk of life-threatening arrhythmias.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol use is admitted to the hospital. He presents with anxiety, tremors, and agitation after his last drink 24 hours ago. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for the control of alcohol withdrawal symptoms? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lorazepam

 

The patient presents with mild alcohol withdrawal symptoms, which commonly include anxiety, tremors, and agitation within 6-24 hours after the last drink. The gold standard treatment for alcohol withdrawal is benzodiazepines, which help manage the symptoms by enhancing the effect of the neurotransmitter GABA, thereby calming the nervous system.

 

Lorazepam is a short-acting benzodiazepine preferred in alcohol withdrawal, especially in patients with liver impairment due to its relatively safer hepatic metabolism compared to long-acting benzodiazepines. It helps reduce withdrawal symptoms and prevent progression to severe complications like delirium tremens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fomepizole: This medication is an alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitor used in the management of methanol or ethylene glycol poisoning. It is not used for treating alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

 

Option C. Disulfiram: Disulfiram is used for long-term maintenance in alcohol dependence by discouraging alcohol intake through aversive effects. It does not play a role in managing acute withdrawal symptoms.

 

Option D. Buspirone: Buspirone is an anxiolytic medication primarily used for generalized anxiety disorders. It is not effective in managing the acute symptoms of alcohol withdrawal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam, are the first-line treatment for managing alcohol withdrawal symptoms, especially in patients with liver concerns.

choices.text: Atropine decreases the adverse effect of diphenoxylate

questions.text: What is the rationale for the use of atropine in combination with diphenoxylate? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) To prevent abuse of diphenoxylate

 

Diphenoxylate is an opioid medication used to treat diarrhea. However, it also has the potential for abuse due to its opioid-like effects. Atropine, an anticholinergic drug, is added to diphenoxylate to discourage abuse. If someone tries to take a higher dose of diphenoxylate to get high, they will also ingest a higher dose of atropine, which will lead to unpleasant side effects like dry mouth, blurred vision, and dizziness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atropine decreases the adverse effect of diphenoxylate: While atropine may counteract some of the cholinergic side effects of diphenoxylate (like excessive sweating or salivation), its primary purpose in this combination is not to reduce adverse effects.

 

Option C. To enhance the antidiarrheal effect: Both diphenoxylate and atropine can slow down gut motility, but the main reason for combining them is not to enhance the antidiarrheal effect.

 

Option D. Atropine produces direct spasmolytic action: Atropine does have some antispasmodic effects, but its primary role in this combination is to deter abuse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atropine is combined with diphenoxylate to discourage abuse of this opioid anti-diarrheal medication.

questions.text: A patient having hypertension, is on thiazides and is complaining of fatigue and hypokalemia. Which of the following drug can prevent potassium loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amiloride

 

Explanation:

 

Thiazide diuretics, such as hydrochlorothiazide, indapamide, chlorthalidone, and metolazone, are known for causing potassium wasting, which can result in hypokalemia and associated symptoms like fatigue. To counteract this effect, potassium-sparing diuretics can be used.

 

Amiloride is an epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) inhibitor, which is a type of potassium-sparing diuretic. It helps prevent potassium loss by inhibiting sodium reabsorption in the distal tubules of the kidneys, thereby reducing potassium excretion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide: This is a loop diuretic, which also causes potassium wasting and is not suitable for preventing potassium loss.

 

Option C. Acetazolamide: This is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor diuretic, which is not typically used for potassium conservation and can also cause electrolyte imbalances.

 

Option D. Indapamide: This is another thiazide-like diuretic, which also causes potassium wasting and does not prevent potassium loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that can be used to prevent potassium loss in patients on thiazide diuretics.

questions.text: What renal function does the formula UV/P represent? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clearance

 

Renal clearance is a measure of the volume of plasma from which a substance is completely removed by the kidneys per unit time. It provides important information about the efficiency with which the kidneys can filter out a substance from the bloodstream and excrete it in the urine.

 

The formula is:

 

Clearance(C) = UV /P ​

 

Where:

 

  • C is the clearance of the substance.
  • U is the concentration of the substance in the urine.
  • V is the urine flow rate (volume of urine produced per unit time).
  • P is the concentration of the substance in the plasma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Filtration fraction: This is the ratio of the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) to the renal plasma flow (RPF).

 

Option B. Tubular secretion: This refers to the active process by which substances are transported from the blood into the renal tubule. While clearance can involve secretion, the formula UV/P specifically calculates overall clearance, not just secretion.

 

Option C. Tubular reabsorption: This refers to the process by which substances are reabsorbed from the renal tubule back into the blood. The UV/P formula does not directly represent reabsorption but overall clearance, which can include filtration and reabsorption processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The formula UV/P is used to calculate the renal clearance of a substance, reflecting the volume of plasma from which the kidneys can completely remove that substance per unit time.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female who had a lumbar puncture continues to have a headache. Which of the following is not recommended? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fluid restriction

 

The patient is experiencing a post-dural puncture headache (PDPH), which can occur after a lumbar puncture due to the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). This type of headache is typically treated with a variety of supportive measures to alleviate symptoms and promote healing.

 

Fluid restriction is not recommended for patients with PDPH.  In fact, liberal fluid intake is advised to help replace the lost CSF and maintain adequate hydration, which can aid in reducing the headache.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low volume blood patch: An epidural blood patch is an effective treatment for PDPH, particularly in refractory cases. It involves injecting a small amount of the patient's own blood into the epidural space to seal the CSF leak.

 

Option B. Increase caffeine: Caffeine is known to help reduce the severity of PDPH due to its vasoconstrictive properties, which can help alleviate the headache.

 

Option D. Stool softeners: Stool softeners are recommended to prevent straining during bowel movements, which can exacerbate the headache. Constipation is common in postoperative patients due to the use of anesthetics and other medications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of post-dural puncture headache, fluid restriction is not recommended. Instead, measures such as epidural blood patches, increased caffeine intake, and stool softeners are utilized to manage symptoms and promote recovery.

questions.text: How will you collect samples for blood culture in a patient with suspected Infective Endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3 aerobic and 3 anaerobic

 

Explanation:

 

Infective endocarditis is diagnosed using Duke's criteria, which includes major and minor criteria. One of the major criteria involves positive blood cultures.

 

For accurate diagnosis, it is essential to collect multiple blood cultures to identify the causative organism reliably.

 

A blood culture set includes both aerobic and anaerobic samples.

 

According to Duke's criteria:

 

  • A minimum of two cultures should be drawn at least 12 hours apart.
  • Ideally, three or more cultures should be collected.
  • When collecting three or more cultures, each culture set includes both aerobic and anaerobic samples.

 

Therefore, for three culture sets, you would collect three aerobic and three anaerobic samples.

 

The rules for collection are:

 

  1. If two culture sets are collected, both should be drawn at least 12 hours apart and both should be positive.
  2. If three or more culture sets are collected, all three should be positive for the same organism.
  3. If more than three culture sets are collected, the majority should be positive for the same organism.
  4. The gap between the first and the last culture should be at least one hour.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For suspected infective endocarditis, the recommended blood culture collection includes three aerobic and three anaerobic samples to ensure accurate diagnosis and identification of the causative organism

questions.text: 18-year-old girl presents with bilateral ptosis and difficulty in chewing and combing. Her problems tend to worsen with activity. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myasthenia Gravis

 

Myasthenia Gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder characterized by weakness and fatigue of the skeletal muscles. The weakness typically worsens with activity and improves with rest, which is a hallmark of the disease. The symptoms are caused by antibodies that block or destroy nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, leading to decreased transmission of nerve impulses to the muscles.

 

In this case, the presence of bilateral ptosis (drooping of the eyelids) and difficulty in activities such as chewing and combing, which worsen with activity, are classic signs of Myasthenia Gravis. These symptoms reflect the muscle fatigue and weakness that are characteristic of the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lambert Eaton Syndrome: This condition also involves muscle weakness, but it typically improves with repeated activity. It is often associated with small cell lung cancer and involves autoantibodies against presynaptic calcium channels, leading to reduced acetylcholine release.

 

Option C. Myotonic dystrophy: This genetic disorder involves progressive muscle wasting and weakness but does not typically present with ptosis and the fluctuating weakness seen in Myasthenia Gravis. It is characterized by myotonia (difficulty relaxing muscles) rather than fatigue with activity.

 

Option D. Guillain Barre syndrome:  An acute autoimmune disorder that affects the peripheral nervous system, leading to rapid onset of muscle weakness and paralysis. It does not present with ptosis and is associated with ascending muscle weakness rather than fatigue that worsens with activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia Gravis is characterized by muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest, with ptosis and difficulty in tasks requiring sustained muscle effort being common symptoms.

questions.text: A patient with hemolytic anemia presents with index finger pain and chest pain. The patient has Hb of 5.6 gm/dl and an increase in unconjugated bilirubin in serum. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sickling crisis

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with hemolytic anemia, evidenced by a low hemoglobin level of 5.6 gm/dl and an increase in unconjugated bilirubin, indicating hemolysis. The specific symptoms of index finger pain and chest pain are highly suggestive of a sickling crisis.

 

In sickle cell disease, patients may experience episodes of severe pain, known as sickle cell crises or vaso-occlusive crises, due to the blockage of blood flow by sickled red blood cells. The index finger pain (dactylitis) and chest pain (acute chest syndrome) are classic manifestations of such crises. Acute chest syndrome is a severe complication of sickle cell disease that presents with chest pain, fever, and pulmonary infiltrates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Microangiopathic anemia: This condition involves the destruction of red blood cells in small blood vessels but does not typically present with the specific symptoms of dactylitis and acute chest syndrome.

 

Option C. Thalassemia: While thalassemia also causes hemolytic anemia, it does not usually present with dactylitis or acute chest syndrome.

 

Option D. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia: This condition involves the immune system attacking red blood cells but lacks the specific signs of sickle cell crisis, such as dactylitis and acute chest syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with hemolytic anemia presenting with severe pain in the fingers (dactylitis) and chest pain (acute chest syndrome), sickle cell crisis is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman complains of ptosis and diplopia that worsens with activity and improves with rest. What is the most sensitive investigation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) EMG (Electromyography)

 

The symptoms of ptosis and diplopia that worsen with activity and improve with rest are characteristic of myasthenia gravis, a neuromuscular disorder caused by autoimmune destruction of acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.

 

The most sensitive investigation for myasthenia gravis is single fiber electromyography (SF-EMG), which detects abnormalities in the neuromuscular transmission by measuring the electrical activity of muscle fibers. Even if single fiber EMG is not specifically mentioned, standard EMG is still highly sensitive and appropriate for diagnosing myasthenia gravis. Another practical test used is repetitive nerve stimulation (RNS), which shows a decremental response in myasthenia gravis patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CT scan chest: This is usually performed in confirmed myasthenia gravis patients to rule out thymoma, but it is not the most sensitive test for diagnosing the condition itself.

 

Option C. Acetylcholinesterase test: Also known as the edrophonium test or Tensilon test, this can be used to diagnose myasthenia gravis by temporarily improving muscle strength. However, it has variable sensitivity and specificity and is less sensitive than EMG.

 

Option D. Nerve conduction velocity: This test is more relevant in the diagnosis of neuropathies, particularly demyelinating neuropathies, where conduction velocities are decreased. It is not the most sensitive test for myasthenia gravis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most sensitive investigation for diagnosing myasthenia gravis is electromyography (EMG), particularly single fiber EMG, which detects abnormalities in neuromuscular transmission.

questions.text: A patient came to emergency with severe breathlessness. CXR is taken and shown below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pleural effusion

 

Explanation:

 

The chest X-ray (CXR) of the patient shows a whiteout on one side with a significant tracheal shift to the opposite side. These findings are indicative of a massive pleural effusion.

 

Pleural effusion: This condition results in the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space, leading to lung compression and a shift of the mediastinum, including the trachea, away from the affected side. The presence of a large whiteout on the X-ray, along with the tracheal deviation to the opposite side, strongly suggests pleural effusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax: This condition would typically present with a hyperlucent (dark) area on the X-ray without lung markings, rather than a whiteout. It also generally causes a tracheal shift towards the opposite side, but the appearance on the X-ray would be different.

 

Option B. Consolidation: This condition involves filling of the alveoli with fluid or other material, leading to a whiteout appearance on the X-ray. However, it does not usually cause a significant tracheal shift.

 

Option C. Collapse: This condition, also known as atelectasis, would cause a shift of the trachea towards the affected side. It can present with a whiteout on the X-ray, but the tracheal deviation would be opposite to that seen in pleural effusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A massive pleural effusion is characterized by a whiteout on the chest X-ray with a significant tracheal shift to the opposite side.

questions.text: Innervation of lateral rectus is by which nerve? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CN VI

 

The lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for moving the eye laterally (abduction), is innervated by the sixth cranial nerve, also known as the abducens nerve. This nerve specifically controls the lateral rectus muscle, allowing for the lateral movement of the eyeball.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CN III (Oculomotor nerve): The oculomotor nerve innervates most of the other extraocular muscles, including the medial rectus, superior rectus, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles. It is not responsible for innervating the lateral rectus muscle.

 

Option B. CN IV (Trochlear nerve): The trochlear nerve innervates only the superior oblique muscle, which is involved in downward and outward movement of the eye. It does not innervate the lateral rectus muscle.

 

Option D. CN VII (Facial nerve): The facial nerve is primarily responsible for the muscles of facial expression. It does not innervate any of the extraocular muscles, including the lateral rectus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral rectus muscle is innervated by the sixth cranial nerve (CN VI), also known as the abducens nerve.

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented with weight gain and hyperpigmentation of palms and soles. He was subsequently diagnosed to have lung cancer. Which of the following is responsible for hyperpigmentation? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Melanocyte Stimulating Hormone (MSH)

 

Explanation:

 

The patient, a chronic smoker, presented with weight gain and hyperpigmentation of the palms and soles and was diagnosed with lung cancer. This clinical scenario suggests the presence of an ectopic ACTH-producing tumor, most commonly associated with small cell lung cancer.

 

In such cases, the excessive ACTH produced by the tumor can lead to Cushing's syndrome.

 

Additionally, ACTH has an intrinsic MSH (Melanocyte Stimulating Hormone) activity due to the shared precursor molecule, proopiomelanocortin (POMC). The MSH part within ACTH stimulates melanocytes, leading to increased melanin production and resulting in hyperpigmentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemosiderin: Hemosiderin is an iron-storage complex. It does not play a role in causing hyperpigmentation in this context.

 

Option C. Neuropeptide Y: Neuropeptide Y is involved in various physiological processes, including regulation of appetite and stress responses, but not in causing hyperpigmentation.

 

Option D. Melanin: While melanin is the pigment responsible for skin color, its production is stimulated by MSH. Thus, MSH is the direct cause of increased melanin and subsequent hyperpigmentation in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of ectopic ACTH production, such as with small cell lung cancer, hyperpigmentation occurs due to the MSH activity of ACTH, which stimulates melanocytes to produce melanin.

questions.text: A patient presented with 2 Lisch nodules in the iris. What is the possible diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neurofibromatosis

 

Lisch nodules are pigmented, benign hamartomas found in the iris of the eye. They are highly specific to Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), also known as von Recklinghausen disease. NF1 is a genetic disorder characterized by the development of multiple benign tumors called neurofibromas, café-au-lait spots, and other neurological and ocular manifestations.

 

Key diagnostic feature:

 

  • Lisch nodules: These are melanocytic hamartomas and are considered a hallmark of NF1. Their presence, particularly when there are two or more, is diagnostic of NF1.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tuberous sclerosis: This genetic disorder is characterized by the growth of benign tumors in multiple organs, including the brain, skin, kidneys, and heart. It is associated with other ocular findings such as retinal hamartomas, but not with Lisch nodules.

 

Option C. Sturge-Weber syndrome: This congenital disorder is associated with a port-wine stain birthmark, neurological abnormalities, and ocular issues like glaucoma, but not with Lisch nodules.

 

Option D. Von Hippel Lindau syndrome: This is a genetic disorder that leads to the formation of tumors and cysts in different parts of the body, particularly the kidneys, pancreas, and central nervous system. It is not associated with Lisch nodules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Lisch nodules in the iris is highly specific for Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), making it a key diagnostic feature for this condition

questions.text: What is the likely ECG change associated with Bedaquiline?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) QT prolongation

 

Explanation:

 

Bedaquiline is a modern anti-tubercular drug used primarily for the treatment of multidrug-resistant (MDR) and extensively drug-resistant (XDR) tuberculosis. One of the significant side effects of bedaquiline is QT prolongation.

 

QT prolongation is a measure of delayed ventricular repolarization, which can be seen on an ECG as an extended QT interval. This side effect is critical as it can predispose patients to potentially fatal arrhythmias, such as Torsades de Pointes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. PR prolongation: This represents delayed atrioventricular conduction and is not a known side effect of bedaquiline.

 

Option C. ST elevation: This is typically associated with myocardial infarction and is not a side effect of bedaquiline.

 

Option D. Wide QRS: This indicates delayed intraventricular conduction and is not associated with bedaquiline.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bedaquiline, an important drug for treating MDR and XDR tuberculosis, is known for causing QT prolongation on ECG.

 

Note - The "Q" in bedaquiline can be a mnemonic to remember this important side effect.

questions.text:
